page.title: 12SHOTESHAM/HOWE LANDSCAPE
page.content: Very gently undulating rising from 50ft and 75ft along The Beck, a tributary of the River Tas, to 150ft. The major{LANDSCAPE}pattern being{ {FIELDS,}either ploughed, with standing crops, stubble or meadowland. The small amount of housing is scattered unless at village centres. {WOODLAND}The area has 3 main woods and numerous small copses. Great Wood, 56 acres of decidous trees Little Wood, 46 acres, a rich Hornbeam wood of probable primary origin. Brooke Wood, 150 acres 85% coniferous. {COMMONLAND}Stubbs Green, 4 acres cut for hay. Howe Common, 5_6 acres, cut once p.a. Shotesham Common, 48_50 acres, enclosed in 1936 and used for grazing cattle, horses and donkeys. Permission to graze an animal being called a 'going' and costs Â£18 p.a Hedges and ditches remain a feature.
